importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's publication, marking the end of Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season and providing context for the events and statistics discussed.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The first seven weeks of the 2025 NFL season, from early September to Week 7, are highlighted as a period of dramatic unpredictability, with numerous lead changes and comebacks, setting the stage for the key events covered in the article.

keyTakeAways: The NFL season has shown increasing unpredictability, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation through Week 7 — the most in NFL history over that span.

The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team since 2007 to recover from a 161-0 record of shutouts with 18+ point leads after three quarters.
Second-year quarterback Bo Nix led a dramatic fourth-quarter surge, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, including a game-winning field goal as time expired.

Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (91.3%) and became the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of his passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards in a single game.

Multiple quarterbacks were benched during the week: Tua Tagovailoa of the Miami Dolphins was replaced by rookie Quinn Ewers after throwing three interceptions, and Justin Fields of the Jets was benched at halftime due to poor performance, replaced by Tyrod Taylor.
The New York Jets remain winless at 0–7, while the Miami Dolphins fell to 1–13 after a 31–6 loss to the Browns, signaling a critical downturn in their seasons.

The Green Bay Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals with a late fourth-quarter touchdown and a turnover on downs, fueled by defensive star Micah Parsons, who recorded his third sack of the game on Arizona's final drive.

The article underscores a broader trend in the NFL: teams are experiencing dramatic comebacks, performance volatility, and quarterback turnover, reflecting both the physical and emotional intensity of the season.

namedEntities.name: Denver Broncos

namedEntities.name: Courtland Sutton

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers

namedEntities.name: Arizona Cardinals

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brissett led the Cardinals’ offense but was overwhelmed by the Packers’ defense, especially Micah Parsons, and failed to secure a winning drive.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parsons was a dominant force for the Packers, recording three sacks and disrupting the Cardinals' final drive, contributing to their upset loss.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tagovailoa was benched after throwing three interceptions, including one returned for a touchdown, highlighting quarterback instability.

namedEntities.name: Quinn Ewers

namedEntities.name: New York Jets

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields

namedEntities.name: Tyrod Taylor

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Panthers defeated the Jets 13–6, with a strong defense and a key loss of starting QB Bryce Young due to injury, adding to the narrative of team resilience and adversity.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Young
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Young was injured during the game and exited mid-second half, which allowed the Panthers to maintain their lead and secure a first road win of the season.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vrabel, who was fired by the Titans in 2024, returned to win his first game against the Patriots, and fans chanted his name, showing a shift in fan sentiment and team dynamics.

namedEntities.name: Mike McDaniel

namedEntities.name: Aaron Glenn

namedEntities.name: Tom Brady

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was marked by dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and significant coaching decisions. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit against the New York Giants, with second-year quarterback Bo Nix leading a fourth-quarter explosion to secure a 33-32 victory. Meanwhile, Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate and achieved a historic milestone in a single game, becoming the first player to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards. On the flip side, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets both suffered devastating losses, with Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields benched due to poor performances. The Jets' head coach Aaron Glenn made a mid-game decision to replace Fields with Tyrod Taylor, highlighting ongoing instability in the team’s quarterback situation. The article underscores the unpredictability of the NFL season, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation — the most in NFL history — and highlights a broader trend of quarterback turnover, dramatic upsets, and evolving team dynamics.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
